Authors:
Susumu Takamatsu, Vasyl P. Heluta, M. haverylenko, Rangsi
Divarangkoon
Title:
Four powdery mildew species with catenate conidia infect
Galium spp.: Molecular and morphological evidence
Abstract:
The Erysiphaceae are a group of obligately biotrophic
fungi that cause powdery mildew disease of angiosperms. Due to their
inability to be cultured on artificial media, the taxonomy of the
Erysiphaceae has generally been based on the morphological
characteristics of fresh as well as herbarium specimens. Thus, several
morphological species with wide host ranges have long been maintained in
this family, even though they clearly consist of several biological
species. Erysiphe galii has been known as a powdery mildew of Galium
spp. Recently, the former E. galii var. galii has been reassessed as
Neoerysiphe galii and E. galii var. riedliana as Golovinomyces
riedlianus, along with a taxonomic revision of the generic concept of
the Erysiphaceae. The present study was conducted to evaluate the
validity of the taxonomic revision of the two varieties of E. galii.
During the course of this study, we found that the Galium powdery
mildews consist of at least four different species, viz. Neoerysiphe
galii, Golovinomyces orontii, G. riedlianus, and an unknown species
collected in Argentina. The latter species is described as a new
species, Golovinomyces calceolariae. The three species belonging to
Golovinomyces are morphologically very similar among one another,
i.e. the discrimination between them is rather difficult. The
morphological differences of the three Golovinomyces species of Galium
are discussed.
